title: 112_hr1165
content: The Act may be cited as the "Transportation Security Administration Ombudsman Act of 2011" and establishes the Transportation Security Administration Ombudsman Office. The "Transportation Security Administration Ombudsman Act of 2011" establishes the Office of the Ombudsman within the Transportation Security Administration. The Ombudsman must have expertise in labor and employment relations with Federal agencies. The Chief Human Capital Officer of the Department of Homeland Security must notify congressional committees within 30 days of appointing, reappointing, or removing an Ombudsman. The Ombudsman must report to the Administrator of the agency to ensure independence. The Ombudsman reports to the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration and the Chief Human Capital Officer of the Department of Homeland Security in case of disputes. The Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security retains the authority to conduct investigations. The Ombudsman's duties include ensuring independence. The Ombudsman for Transportation Security Administration employees conducts outreach, evaluates complaints objectively, provides assistance, and informs complainants of investigation status and recommendations. The Ombudsman for Transportation Security Administration employees is responsible for addressing issues identified through fact-finding, maintaining confidentiality of complaints and inquiries, and submitting an annual report to congressional committees. The Ombudsman must report on actions taken by the office and objectives of those actions by September 30 each year. The Ombudsman for Transportation Security Administration employees submits an annual report to congressional committees by September 30 each year. The report includes statistical information on complaints, problems encountered by complainants, policy recommendations made to the Administrator, and an inventory of items described. The Ombudsman submits an annual report to congressional committees with statistical information on complaints, policy recommendations, and an inventory of items for action. The report is submitted directly without prior comment or amendment by the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration. The Ombudsman can issue additional reports on TSA activities. The TSA Administrator must provide contact information for the Ombudsman online. The term 'appropriate congressional committee' is defined in the section. The chapter is amended by adding new items related to subchapter II at the end. Authorization of Appropriations for implementing section 44946 of title 49, United States Code, is set at $575,000 for fiscal years 2012, 2013, and 2014.
